title: Climate change will make the Mediterranean too hot for British holidaymakers who will flock to resorts in the Balkans by 2100
text:
7 shares 7
View
comments
Southern Europe is currently a favourite holiday destination for Brits jetting off on an end-of-summer jaunt - but that all may change with climate change forcing them to head east.
As Mediterranean destinations reach record temperatures, some experts predict that holidaymakers will opt for alternative getaways to avoid the heat.
In the last month alone, Europe has experienced a record heat wave across Germany, France, Portugal and Spain, such as in Cordoba, where temperatures soared to a sizzling 43.7C in July.
A study investigating the effects of climate change predicts that Brits will no longer summer in the Mediterranean in the future. Pictured: a crowded beach in Barcelona, Spain
An investigation into the effects of climate change, made by the European Commission, predicted an end to Brits' Mediterranean exodus, in favour of locations such as the Balkans.
The experts also predict that if British holidaymakers do still opt to vacation in southern Europe, the trips will be shorter and during the off-season to avoid the sweltering heat.

When the journey really IS the best part: The scenic roads... According to the study, Spain and Bulgaria will likely be hit worst by the effects of climate change.
Meanwhile, resorts in Estonia, Latvia, Slovenia and Slovakia are likely to benefit most.
'One could expect tourists would distribute their holiday pattern more evenly during the year and take shorter holidays in order to benefit, for instance, from more clement weather conditions during the other seasons,' the report reads.
Instead, the EU report believes that the Balkans will rise in popularity, in particular the beaches in Estonia (pictured) and Latvia
These findings by the EU's Joint Research Centre are based on the larger trend of rising global temperatures, which are expected to increase by 2C by the end of the century.
It also analyses the potential impact of climate change on tourism demand in the EU and provides long-term projections - through 2100 - accounting for climate adaptation in terms of holiday duration and frequency.
Ultimately, tourism revenues in these warm-climate countries could be slashed by up to 0.45 per cent of GDP per year, while the north of the continent would gain by as much as 0.32 per cent.
This would undoubtedly shock those who live in the Mediterranean year round, as many people's livelihoods rely on the influx of tourists each summer.
